text.text: A Guide to King's Cross

Find yourself in King's Cross and not in transit, questions might be asked as to just what it is you're up to. Because this is London's contentious symbol of Peak Development - where the prostitution and destitution of the 80s and 90s have been replaced by the HQ's of the likes of the Guardian and Google.

Developers have rolled in and gone wild, transforming it into a sleek and slick international hub of offices, chains and traffic jams. Consequently, word is it's lacking a bit of character. But we kinda enjoy sifting through the dirt to find the diamonds, so here we are getting to grips with the strange grey lands of King's Cross.
Best for... a hearty, warming lunch

tip.text:
***Closed Jan 2019***

Lunch fodder isn't scarce around these roads, but if you want something a little heartier, a little fresher and, admittedly, a lil' bit more spenny, Niven's is your boy. In a cosy abode that feels akin to a country house kitchen with a large communal table and larder, the animated owner Niven jolts around pulling the strings: making coffees, barking orders and passionately chatting with regulars. Years as a record-producer eating stale sandwiches and limp salads led him to wild thoughts of European-style menus of the day. And he's walking the walk.

Whilst they do a mean fry up in the morning, it really heats up in here at around 12.30pm. That's when loyal regulars (largely techy office workers) cram through the doors with a slightly crazy look in their eye, drawn to dishes such as beetroot gratin, mac n cheese or chicken and bacon pies that sit up on the hotplate by the window. Lunch comes in at Â£8 for a regular and it's exactly as you'd want it: warmingly tasty and filling. You can also grab salad, sandwiches and other baked goods if that's your feeling.

text.text:
Lunch fodder isn't scarce around these roads, but if you want something a little heartier, a little fresher and, admittedly, a lil' bit more spenny, Niven's is your boy. In a cosy, country-house kitchen abode the animated owner Niven jolts around pulling the strings: making coffees, barking orders and passionately chatting with regulars. 

Years as a record-producer, eating stale sandwiches and limp salads, led him to wild thoughts of European-style menus of the day. And he's walking the walk. At around 12.30pm, loyal regulars cram through the doors with a slightly crazy look in their eye, drawn to warming, home-cooked dishes such as beetroot gratin, mac n cheese and chicken and bacon pies sitting on the hotplates by the window.
Best for... a caffeine pit-stop

tip.text:
For beans off the beaten track, we'd tip Frequency - the kind of minimalist cafe pit-stop that would fit in just great somewhere like Broadway Market. Really it would, it'd make all kinds of friends. Set up by a super friendly couple, Justo and Joey, Frequency keeps things simple: decor is all pine wood and white walls, whilst a calming soundtrack puts you in the perfect state of mind to suddenly ramp up your heart rate with some caffeine.

That caffeine, incidentally, comes from Workshop and is really quite delicious. For eats, you've got pastries, croissants and brownies to satisfy the sweet; sandwiches and these delicate lil' open Argentine empanadas for the savoury. Those empanadas are a little on the expensive side but they are very tasty, so the ball is in your court. Come evening, you might be expecting this cafe to close. Wrong! Instead it dishes out some wine and a couple of beers on tap, the lights dim and it becomes a classic, and very discreet, Date Night Spot.

text.text: For beans off the beaten track, we'd tip Frequency - the kind of minimalist cafe pit-stop that would fit in just great somewhere like Broadway Market. Really it would, it'd make all kinds of friends. Set up by a super friendly couple, Gusto and Joey, Frequency keeps things simple: decor is all pine wood and white walls, whilst a calming soundtrack puts you in the perfect state of mind to suddenly ramp up your heart rate with some caffeine, courtesy of Workshop.
Best for... a community garden with a huge heart

tip.text:
This is one of those integral community gardens that, frankly, should be found in every single neighbourhood. Calthorpe Project is a small green oasis of calm in the heart of King's Cross; a multi-purpose space offering that peace, that tranquility, that sense of community that everyone needs, no matter how big and tough they might make out.

Set up with the aim of improving the physical and emotional well-being of those who live, work or study in Camden, this is home to a horticultural volunteering programme, food growing, a vegetarian cafe and a 5-a-side futsal pitch. The cafe does toasties, salads and spinach and feta pies to keep things ticking over. There's even beer for sale and a pizza oven in use come Friday evenings in the summer. Not the biggest community garden you'll come across, but one with a big old heart.

text.text:
This is one of those integral community gardens that, frankly, should be found in every single neighbourhood. Calthorpe Project is a small green oasis of calm in the heart of King's Cross; a multi-purpose space offering that peace, that tranquility, that sense of community that everyone needs, no matter how big and tough they might make out. 

Set up with the aim of improving the physical and emotional well being of those who live, work or study in Camden, this is home to a horticultural volunteering programme, food growing, a vegetarian cafe and a 5-a-side futsal pitch. The cafe does toasties, salads and spinach and feta pies to keep things ticking over.
Best for... a true hidden gem

tip.text:
Every so often, we make our way down some grey steps on a non-descript street and get the unmistakable sense we're onto something hot. Roti King really is a king: serving up authentic, tasty and cheap Malaysian food from an open kitchen nook to a tightly packed basement where those in the know squeeze in, wrapping their fingers all over soft flakey rotis dipped in perfectly spiced curries.

When it gets busy - and it does at lunch - a pretty lively hubbub envelops the space, transporting you to a street food canteen someplace exotic where several languages fill the air. The key here is to share a few dishes with a pal or two - and with menu selects coming in at around Â£7, this is the kind of hidden gem you're going to feel all kinds of smug telling your friends about.

text.text:
Every so often, we make our way down some narrow steps on a non-descript street and get the unmistakable sense we're onto something hot. We like to call it a Hidden Gem (and that's copyrighted - if you see someone using that, let us know). Roti King really is a king: serving up authentic, tasty and cheap Malaysian food from an open kitchen nook to a tightly packed basement where those in the know squeeze in, wrapping their fingers all over delicious rotis dipped in perfectly spiced curries.

When it gets busy - and it does at lunch - a pretty lively hubbub envelops the space, making it feel like you're in a street food canteen somewhere exotic. Dishes are around Â£7 and the lunch special is true to its name: two mains for Â£5-7. The kind of place that you're going to feel all kinds of smug telling your friends about.
Best for... canalside literature

tip.text:
If you were flicking through the pictorial version of the Urban Dictionary and came across the word charming, you'd probably find a pic of Word on the Water, the canalboat bookshop. Formerly a bit of a nomad that drifted up and down Regent's Canal, a little while back it dropped anchor (metaphorically) near Granary Square, which is just great because it means we always know exactly where it is at all times, just like you.

Packed full of second hand books, as soon as you squeeze in you're gonna feel a lot more cosy, a lot more literary and likely a lot more intelligent. There's an armchair here, a cat there and lots of books everywhere. The roof also plays host to readings, poetry slams and music performances as and when.

text.text:
Charming seems like a pretty apt word for Word on the Water, the canalboat bookshop. Formerly a bit of a nomad that drifted up and down Regent's Canal, a little while back it dropped anchor/used rope to tie itself up near Granary Square, which is just great because it means we always know exactly where it is at all times. Just like you. 

Packed full of second hand books, as soon as you wander in you're gonna feel a lot more cosy, a lot more literary and a lot more intelligent. There's an armchair here, a cat there and lots of books everywhere.
Best for... a Japanese take on veganism

tip.text:
Itadaki Zen is about eating good food and spreading good chi, and we're into it. These cats like to focus on the healing qualities of food, believing that food has some serious medicinal properties, and their dishes focus on utilising them to their fullest. Rice, root veg, seaweed, soya beans and other organic products are recurrent ingredients on the menu, as a well the mantra that a balanced dish is essential for a strong, healthy and happy metabolism - and you know those metabolisms are all the rage right now.

Theyâ€™ve also got plenty of artsy fartsy workshops to pair with all that soulful healing. They aim to get people sharing ideas whilst learning about their projects - which is like, the zennest thing ever.

text.text:
Itadaki Zen is about eating good vegan Japanese food and spreading good chi, and we're into it. These cats like to focus on the healing qualities of food, believing that food has some serious medicinal properties, and their dishes focus on utilising them to their fullest. 

Rice, root veg, seaweed, soya beans and other organic products are recurrent ingredients on the menu, as a well the mantra that a balanced dish is essential for a strong, healthy and happy metabolism - and you know those metabolisms are all the rage right now.
Best for... treating the ears

tip.text:
Stepping into Spiritland is like entering a time warp to bougie 70s New York, where affairs could be conducted in places with a bit of class about them. An audiophile bar, cafe and restaurant, this is a place where every last detail has been meticulously thought through to leave a treat for the senses - where you could happily spend hours surrounded by the soft, glowing orbs of light, submerging yourself in potent cocktails and getting into something serious.

The specially designed sound system is definitely centre stage and is put in the hands of excellent selectors every night of the week to drop grooving, crystal-clear jams: Auto Shazam is a must. It's a romantic, heady spot that has 'wooing' written all over it - although you might end up covering your date's mouth so you can hear the music.

text.text:
Stepping into Spiritland is like entering a time warp to uptown, bougie 70s New York, where affairs could be conducted in places with a bit of class about them. An audiophile bar, cafe and restaurant, this place is a real treat for the senses; where you could easily spend hours surrounded by the soft, glowing orbs of light, sipping on cocktails and getting into something serious.

Part of London's growing wave of audiophile spots, the specially designed world-class soundsystem is definitely centre stage and is put in the hands of excellent selectors every night of the week to drop beautiful, grooving, crystal clear jams. Auto Shazam will be needed. It's a romantic, heady spot that has 'wooing' written all over it - although you might end up covering your date's mouth so you can hear the music.
Best for... a pint of escapism

tip.text:
The Racketeer is a cut above your usual pub, with its fine wine, craft beers and pretty impressive cocktails. What was formerly a classic old man pub called The Carpenter had a pretty dramatic facelift, sending the locals into a rant about gentrification. They likely had a fair point but soon came round to the irresistible charm of the place. It's hella cosy now. What's not to like about original tiles, deep blue walls, and a magical walled garden? Oh and happy hour cocktails Monday to Wednesday?

In an ideal world you'll be booking the soft leather armchairs in the back room and gazing into the embers of the wood burning stove or your boo's eyes - up to you. The cocktails pack a real punch - we got a little wavey on a Hanky Panky - and are all kinds of tasty. You can't go wrong with their Penicillin in a Storm, made with blended scotch, ginger syrup, lemon, Laphroaig 10, and a little porter top. It's got a fun slushy texture with grownup flavours. The menu sticks to simple sharing platters and we'd vouch for the cheese board - heavenly creaminess.

text.text:
We're all for a drinking hole with a bit of heritage about it and this one has been providing refuge for boozers since the 1800s. After an impressive (and slightly controversial) restoration project, its latest guise is the Racketeer: a certified charmer full of original Victorian tiles, deep blue walls and a magical walled garden out back. 

It's somehow got an old world Cuban kind of vibe to it, elevating the simple pleasure of sipping a pint to the realms of exotic escapism. The cocktails are also more than a passing thought too.
Best for... a BYOB group gathering

tip.text:
A recent study by the Government found that people who lived in areas with a decent Vietnamese BYOB restaurant were 175% happier. So praise be for King's Cross staple Sen Viet which is exactly as we want it: inexpensive, flavourful and very accommodating to groups who wanna pop a few bottles and get a little loose with their meal.

The decor has that comforting garishness that all reputable Vietnamese places are about: slightly gaudy orange lighting with dark wood and decorative quirks hanging about the place. Food-wise, the extensive menu has all the usual fare ranging from phos to noodles to meat dishes to baguettes. Our tip would be the banh mi heo nuong (chargrilled pork) baguette or the rare beef pho. This is ideal for a group commune and word has spread, so you might need to book.

text.text:
A recent study by the Government found that people who lived near a decent Vietnamese BYOB restaurant were 175% happier. So praise be for King's Cross staple Sen Viet which is exactly as we want it: inexpensive, flavourful and very accommodating to groups who wanna pop a few bottles and get a little loose with their meal.

The decor has that comforting garishness that all reputable Vietnamese places are about: slightly gaudy orange lighting with dark wood and decorative quirks hanging about the place. Food-wise, the extensive menu has all the usual fare - our tip would be the banh mi heo nuong (chargrilled pork) or the rare beef pho. This is ideal for a group commune and word has spread, so you might need to book.
Best for... a traditional boozer

tip.text:
There are plenty of shitty drinking holes to find yourself in near King's Cross but The Queen's Head is not one of them. This is an intimate, bustling Victorian joint which keeps things simple: 'the way it used to be', we imagine someone might say. Though not us, we don't really know how things used to be.

There's a big selection of beers and ales, with three real ale pumps and craft specialities from across the globe. The atmosphere is also nice and jovial - there's no music unless the piano in the corner gets some action or they've got one of their jazz nights on. You can also have a go at dominoes or backgammon if that's your game.

text.text:
There are plenty of shitty drinking holes to find yourself wallowing in near King's Cross but The Queen's Head is not one of them. This is an intimate, bustling Victorian joint which keeps things simple: 'the way it used to be', we imagine someone might say. Though not us, we don't really know how things used to be.  

There's a big selection of beers and ales, with three real ale pumps and craft specialities from across the globe. The atmosphere is also nice and jovial - there's no music unless the piano in the corner gets some action or they've got one of their Jazz nights on. You can also have a go at dominoes or backgammon if that's your game.
Best for... a cheap and homely Thai

tip.text:
Do you like frills? If the answer is yes, please move on. But if the answer is 'fuck no I don't like frills at all', let us welcome you into the warming embrace of Paolina's Thai Cafe, where the amiable Paolina serves up homely and satisfying Thai grub within an intimate, authentic-feeling cafe that has all the welcoming vibes you'd like to imagine would greet you were you to stay at someone's house in Thailand.

It's a verified cheap eat with most meals around the Â£7 mark: our tip would be to come in at lunchtime where you can get into a tasty fragrant green Thai curry for just Â£6.50. And to top it all off, it's BYOB.

text.text:
Do you like frills? If the answer is yes, please move on. But if the answer is 'fuck no I don't like frills at all', let us welcome you into the warming embrace of Paolina's Thai Cafe. This family-run joint serves up homely and satisfying Thai grub within an intimate, authentic-feeling cafe; rough round the edges but with the unmistakeable feeling of someone's home.

It's a verified cheap eat with most meals around the Â£7 mark: our tip would be to come in at lunchtime where you can get into a tasty fragrant green Thai curry for just Â£6.50. And to top it all off, it's BYOB.
